metadata.title: Lab-on-paper micro- and nano-analytical devices: Fabrication, modification, detection and emerging applications

sections.text:
with specific (bio)analytical examples. A conclusion and outlook section discusses the challenges and future prospectives in this field.
Keywords Paper-based chip .Microdevice . Nanodevice . Micromaterials . Nanomaterials . Fabrication . Biosassay

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Micro total analysis systems (μTAS), also called lab-on-a-chip [1, 2], have the ambitious goal of integrating all functions of sample pretreatment, reagents delivery, mixing, separation and detection in a minimized chip through the inside microchannels network [3]. The lab-on-a-chip devices are usually made out of polymers (e.g. poly(dimethyl siloxane)) and glass. With respect to the traditional analytic systems, the lab-on-achip devices offer several advantages, such as system integration, portability, speed of analysis, low consumption of reagents and samples, enhanced ability to carry out parallel processing, and superior control of reaction conditions [3–8]. Whitesides and co-workers raised the first concept for using patterned paper substrate as lab-on-a-chip platform for multiplex analyte assays in 2007. Since then, paper-based analytical devices have been attracting more and more attentions [9–11]. They are regarded as one new branch of lab-on-a-chip, while with more obvious advantages of simplicity, portability, disposability and low cost, etc. [12] (Fig. 1a). It should be noticed that not all the paper-based platforms are carried out though the microfluidic channels, thus paper-based chips (PCs) or labon-paper should more accurately represent the analytical kits using paper as substrates. As can be seen in Fig. 1b, over the past years, especially since 2012, sharply increasing research efforts have been dedicated to their fabrication, modification, and quantification [10, 13–17]. Various detection techniques Yuanhong Xu and Mengli Liu contributed equally to this work. * Yuanhong Xu yhxu@qdu.edu.cn * Jingquan Liu jliu@qdu.edu.cn 1 College of Materials Science and Engineering, Qingdao University, Qingdao 266071, China 2 Laboratory of Fiber Materials and Modern Textile, The Growing Base for State Key Laboratory, Qingdao University, Qingdao 266071, China 3 Collaborative Innovation Center for Marine Biomass Fibers, Materials and Textiles of Shandong Province, Qingdao University, Qingdao 266071, China
can be used for the lab-on-paper assay, thereinto colorimetry, electrochemistry (EC), electrochemiluminescence (ECL) and chemiluminescence (CL) take up to 87.28 % of the lab-onpaper analysis (Fig. 1c). With the development of micro- andnanoscience, micro−/nanomaterials with superior optical, electronic properties can be combined to the development of paper-based analytical devices for enhanced lab-on-paper functions such as signal generation and amplification [18].
Source: ISI Web of Knowledge from 2007 to 2015. These advances place lab-on-paper research in a prime position to develop inexpensive, disposable, portable analytical devices for applications in environment monitoring [19, 20], food safety control [21, 22], diagnostic tests [23, 24] and the genetic engineering, etc. [25, 26] (Fig. 1a). Besides the research works, some literature reviews have also been given to summarize the fabrication methods, applications and related detection techniques as well as detectors and readout of the lab-on-paper works [13, 19, 27–34]. For example, Cate et al. [27] gave detailed summarization and discussion of the labon-paper applications and corresponding detection techniques in the time range fromOctober 2012 to October 2014. Specific reviews such as on the development of inkjet printing fabrication techniques [35] or detection techniques such as EC [36], CL and ECL [37] in paper-based chips (PB-chips) or have also been proposed recently. Many new paper-based research works have been constantly emerging. This review herein updates the latest research advances, providing comprehensive and critical insights into the fabrication materials and methods for the PB-chips. The μPs/NPs those have been used for improving the functions of PB-chips have been summarized and discussed. Moreover, detection techniques were employed as
the classification criteria to discuss the corresponding applications of the paper-based kits taking the latest related works since November 2014 as examples, in addition, the challenges and future prospective have also been discussed.
Features of using paper in lab-on-a-chip devices
Paper-based materials have drawn increasing interest as a potential material for sensors and devices in analytical and clinical chemistry due to their versatility, high abundance and low cost [33, 38, 39]. The use of paper for fabricating microchip devices is an absolutely wise choice for several reasons [40–43]: (i) paper is cheap and abundant. In comparison with other microfluidic substrates, paper (0.1 cents.dm−2) is 200 times less expensive than poly(ethylene terephthalate) and 1000 times less expensive than glass; (ii) Paper is easily stored in a small space, ready for instant use, furthermore, it can be mounted as reduced volume device with well portability; (iii) Paper is compatible with biological samples because it is typically made of cellulose or cellulose-polymer blends; (iv) Paper can be patterned by traditional photolithography processes, or by alternatives methods for mass production of analytical devices in a faster and cheaper way than glass or polymer microfluidic devices [11]; (v) Paper usually exhibits wicking effect, which makes passive transport of fluids without active pumping on the PB-chips; (vi) Paper surface can be modified to afford a wide variety of functional groups by binding many analytes such as proteins, DNA, or small molecules [7] to obtain simple and fast detection devices; (vii) The after
treatment procedure of the used PB-chips is simple andwithout pollution, which can be folded, curled, cut and reproduced.

sections.heading: Choice of paper
sections.text:
Paper is a kind of cheap and easy-available materials with a wide range of choices. Filter paper has seen widespread use for producing PB-chips due to its strong wicking ability, high hydroscopic property and cost-effectiveness [44–46]. For example, based on the laser induced photothermal effect, micro- and nanostructured paper fibrils were favorable for the formation of highly dense metal nanoparticles (NPs) after a single shot of laser exposure. Accordingly, an eco-friendly and ultrasensitive paper substrate was proposed for surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) with performance close to single molecule detection [47]. According to the versatile applications, different chromatography papers have been adopted for special requirements.
Whatman No. 1 chromatography paper was widely applied owning to its clean surface, uniform thickness, wicking properties, medium retention and flow rate. Whatman No. 4 chromatography paper with the pore size of 20–25 μm was also applied for fabrication of diagnostic devices [46]. The ITW Technicloth wipers can also be used as the paper substrate to fabricate three-dimensional (3D) microfluidic devices by stacking layers of patterned paper and double-sided adhesive tape [48]. Nitrocellulose (NC) provides high protein-binding capability due to charge-charge interactions and weak secondary forces. Thus NC is shown to be an ideal protein immobilization paper substrate based on its porous 3D structure [49]. In particular, Al-Tamimi et al. have compared three different paper substrates including drink coaster blotting paper, Whatman No. 4 filter paper and Kleenex towel paper for the detection of human blood type, it was found that Kleenex paper with more porous had enhanced ability to elute nonagglutinated blood [50]. Instead of using listed papers as the main material to fabricate PB-chips, paper towels and other composite papers have also been reported as a suitable platform in sensor technologies [2, 51]. We have summarized the main components, advantages and prices of different kinds of paper choices in Table 1 as follows.
Methods for fabrication of paper-based chips (PB-chips)
Many fabrication methods for PB-chips have been presented until now [59–63], most of which create hydrophobic walls in hydrophilic paper to form the hydrophilic area for regents flowing and detection. The methods can be classified into two main methodologies: one-step ones of selective hydrophobization (SH) and two-step ones of entire hydrophobization followed by selective dehydrophobization
(EH-SDH) process [19] (Table 2). All of the fabrication approaches have their advantages and disadvantages in terms of cost, simplicity, resolution, availability of reagents and applicable printing equipment. Some terms are described in
Table 2, which are helpful to make a choice to select the method for fabricating the PB-chips for a specific application.

sections.heading: Photolithography technique
sections.text:
Photolithographic processes are the foundation of this field and have been extensively used to fabricate microfluidic devices [72]. Traditional photolithography processes to fabricate PBchips were first reported byWhitesides’ group in 2007 [11]. As shown in Fig. 2a, chromatography paper was firstly patterned by photoresist (e.g. SU-8 2010) and was then exposed to the UV light through a photomask. After exposure, uncured photoresist was removed with solvent, leaving hydrophobic, cured photoresist barriers within the paper. Finally, the entire paper was treated with oxygen plasma to form the well defined hydrophilic areas separated by the hydrophobic lines. For detections of different substances, the appropriate reagents were added in their respective hydrophilic test zones. However, most conventional photoresist is much less flexible than paper, and the paper-based devices may be damaged by bending and folding [65, 68]. Moreover, the fabrication process is relatively laborious, time consuming, and requires sophisticated instrumentation usually located in expensive clean rooms that are not always readily accessible for researchers [7].
To reduce the cost and enhance the simplicity of fabrication and simultaneously provide complex functions for the PB-chips, a rapid method for laboratory prototyping of microfluidic devices in paper called FLASH (Fast Lithographic Activation of Sheets) was further developed (Fig. 2b) based on photolithography, but required only a UV lamp and a hotplate. No cleanroom or special facilities were needed. Photomasks for patterning PB-chips can be printed using a photocopier or ink-jet printer, or drawn by hand using a waterproof black pen. This method provided paper channels with dimensions as narrow as 200 μm in width and 70 μm in height. During the later years, the researchers have further reported many works on PB-chips fabrication method based on the time-saving, low-cost and easilyhandle photolithography and modified ones [6, 12, 45, 48, 51, 64, 73–76]. For example, as shown in Fig. 2c, He et al. developed a facile method for PB-chips fabrication by coupling octadecyltrichlorosilane (OTS) to paper fibers to form hydrophobic area of the paper substrate. The hydrophobized paper was then processed by UV-exposing of the OTS coating through a region-selectively quartz mask with pre-designed channel network. Well-defined hydrophobic/hydrophobic boundary by the modified lithography, by which the resolution for hydrophilic channels can reached 233 ± 30 μm [64].
Plasma treatment and inkjet etching techniques
Plasma treatment can be used to pattern microfluidic structures onto Whatman filter paper in developing low-cost analytical devices [19, 46, 65, 66]. The paper was first hydrophobized in a solution of alkyl ketene dimmer, and then treated using plasma in conjunction with a mask to form well defined hydrophilic channels. Besides the advantages listed in
Table 2, the patterned paper also sustained their flexibility, surface topography and contained some functional elements such as control switches, microfilters, and microreactors, etc. In the process using inkjet etching technique to pattern a sensing paper, hydrophilic channels were formed by first soaking the filter paper in poly(styrene) solution contained in toluene. The hydrophilic region was then defined by inkjet deposition of toluene to dissolve the poly(styrene) away from selected regions. This etching technology allowed fabricating flow patterns with resolutions in the several hundred micrometer range [21, 67]. These two fabrication techniques are also industryscale and proved to be amenable for mass production due to their relatively low fabrication cost [30].

sections.heading: Plotting technique
sections.text:
Plotting technique can be used to create flow channels and sensing areas on paper substrates [68, 69]. The fabrication process is schematically shown in Fig. 3a. Various paper devices (e.g. shape-, number-, and color-coded) for multianalyte analysis can be constructed using different templates with corresponding patterns (see Fig. 3b-d). Elastomeric polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) can also be used as a plotter to generate hydrophilic channels. After curing the printed PDMS, the paper-based device allowed bending or folding without destruction of the channel. Moreover, this technique is suited for nearly any research laboratory, even in very remote locations, to fabricate PB-chips for the rapid prototyping of hand-held, visually read, diagnostics analysis, or other purposes [68, 69]. Since the plotting technique is a continuous line drawing method, it is a little difficult to dispense the liquid
amount, therefore, limiting the resolution with minimum feature sizes of ~1 mm [67].

sections.heading: Printing techniques
sections.text: Compare with the fabrication methods described above, printing technique is pretty mature and versatile, and has been used for various fields [46, 77, 78]. It is believed that printing technique can be adopted by the scientific and industrial community for the fabrication of PB-chips with low cost and abundant production.

sections.heading: Inkjet printing
sections.text:
Inkjet printing is a relatively inexpensive alternative to fabricate paper-based microfluidic quantitative devices in mass production, requiring only a single printing apparatus [21, 35, 67]. Balu et al. further utilized the desktop printing technology to pattern super-hydrophobic paper chip with highsurface-energy black ink, which controlled the adhesion forces on water drops in parallel and perpendicular directions. This design allows liquid droplets remaining accessible for further quantitative testing and analysis after simple qualitative on-chip testing [79]. Inkjet printing can be used for not only patterning of microchannels on PB-chips but also the deposition of the reagents required for sensing [15]. For example, Hossain and Risio et al. introduced a bioactive paperbased chip that immobilized the biocompatible, enzymedoped, sol-gel-based inks through this method [61, 80]. The fabricated bioactive paper device can be used to perform ABO and rhesus (RhD) blood typing tests [81].
Despite the distinct superiorities of inkjet printing such as simplicity, low cost as well as mass production, one problem to be considered in the technique is that the cartridges and printers may be easily damaged by the organic solvents, mainly due to the strong organic solvent or hydrophobic materials (e.g. hexane, heptane and toluene) contained in the printing solutions [82, 83]. Thus inks those contain weak organic solvents are desirable. For instance, a kind of permanent marker ink being composed of a colorant, a hydrophobic resin and a

Since being free of expensive instruments and strong solvents, this improved inkjet printing technique is affordable worldwide with minimum cost [83].

sections.heading: Wax printing technique
sections.text:
Wax printing is a simple and low-cost patterning technique based on themelting of solid wax printed onto the porous paper substrate for microfluidic applications [9, 70, 71, 84]. Initially, the fluidic layout was printed onto the chromatographic or filter
paper with a commercial wax ink printer. Then the wax-printed paper was heated to melt the wax that consequently diffused both vertically and horizontally via capillarity through the porous paper, forming hydrophobic barriers across the paper. The simplicity, low cost, and speed of the wax printing method make it very promising for mass production of PB-chips (a set of PB-chips in less than 5 min). Nevertheless, the smallest width of a channel produced by this process was found to be around 550 μm, which is quite higher than those usually obtained by photolithographic methods [9, 71].
The use of wax printer was also expanded to use nitrocellulose (NC) membranes for protein immobilization and corresponding analysis [70]. One advantage of using NC membrane is that the average pore size is quite small (0.45 μm) and uniform. For this reason, the wax penetration process during baking is much slower and can be controlled more precisely. However, these PB-chips suffered from limitations such as in sensitivity and reproducibility. Thus, a new strategy was developed to improve the analytical performances of gold nanoparticles (Au NPs)-based lateral flow assay by using barriers (pillars) deposited onto the surface of NC membrane via wax printing technique. The effect of the introduction of such wax-printed pillars provided almost 3-fold sensitivity improvement compared to that of a conventional free-barrier PB-chips [84].
Screen printing technique and fabrication techniques for electrodes on PB-chips
Screen printing technique offers a convenient and costeffective way for printing images through transferring the carbon ink or other printable materials onto paper substrate surface. It is with flexibility in design, ease of chemical modification, and ability to produce with minimal external technology [12]. By choosing different patterning agents such as carbon ink or wax, this method can be applied for create various function units of the PB-chips. For instance, by combining screen printing with the wax patterning method, a lowcost wax screen-printing one for the PCs fabrication was established, which is rapid, inexpensive, simple, and may be equipped with a hydrophobic barrier of controllable width [71].
Up to this date, screen printing technique has drawn considerable attention in many EC and ECL systems due to its numerous advantages [4, 86]. As shown in Fig. 4a, to develop a paper-based electrochemical platform, a three-electrode system consisting of a counter electrode, reference electrode and working electrode should be integrated onto the paper substrate [14, 87, 88]. The three-electrode system on PB-chips can also be designed with the working electrode and counter electrode laying on one side and the reference electrode laying on the other (Fig. 4b) [14]. Ease manipulation is one distinct characteristics of the screen printing technology, since the
kinds and components of the printable materials can be discretionally chosen based on the specific requirements. Taking this advantage, our group [4] proposed a simple and time-saving one-step process for fabricating the electrode system for PB-chips based ECL sensing. The ECL reagent (Fig. 4c) or materials containing ECL coreactent species (BPEIG) (Fig. 4d) was firstly mixed with the carbon ink paste or functionalized grapheme (PSSG or BPEIG), then the mixture was directly screen-printed on the PB-chips. The as-prepared ECL sensing platform on the PB-chips showed excellent reproducibility and analysis performance for both tripropylamine (TPA) and tetracycline hydrochloride (TCH) detections. Hence, the one-step screen-printing process for fabricating paper-based ECL sensor was confirmed with the advantages of simplicity, high efficiency and potential applicability.
The electrodes on paper can also be drawn with patterning instrument that filled with conductive ink such as pencil and rollerball pens [31, 89], or painted, printed with an ink-jet system, through a screen template [45, 73]. In addition, more sophisticated micromachining methods are also in use: electron beam evaporation, sputtering [90], laser annealing [91], electroplating [92] and photolithography [93, 94]. The most widely used materials for creating the electrodes are conductive inks such as carbon inks, copper, gold or aluminium ink for fabricating working and counter electrodes while silver/ silver chloride ink is used for the reference electrodes [12, 14, 95, 96].

sections.heading: Other fabrication methods
sections.text:
Apart from the methods mentioned above, there are also other techniques to fabricate and modify the PB-chips such as flexographic printing, laser treatment, etc. [97–99]. In the method of flexographic printing, the polystyrene was printed to make paper hydrophobic without any heat treatment, which was enabled to form very thin fluidic channels on paper. It was compatible with roll-to-roll flexography units found in many printing houses, making it an ideal method for large-scale production of paper-based fluidic structures [97, 98].
A type of paper-based microfluidics with high resolution can also be fabricated based on only a common cutter controlled by the software program [99]. Similarly, the PB-chips can be fabricated using embossing and Bcut-and-stack^ methods from omniphobic paper and it was obtained that fluid flowing through these devices had the similar behaviour as that of fluid in an open-channel microfluidic devices [100]. Based on a desktop stereolithography 3D printer, a facile method was proposed for fabricating PB-chips with dynamic mask photo curing [101]. Origami techniques [102, 103] and craft punch patterning [23] have also been used to prepare paper-based fluidic batteries.
Modification of PB-chips with microand nano-materials
The fabricated PB-chips were supposed to be able to fulfill the analysis functions such as sample pretreatment, reagents delivery, mixing, separation and detection. Although the PBchips possess portability and disposability for a variety of applications, there is still large space for their improvements such as in stability and detection sensitivity. As a result, many strategies for PB-chips modification have been proposed including those assisted by micro- and nanomaterials [18, 104, 105], which possess superiorities of unique optical properties, large surface areas, high electrical conductivity, easy surface functionalization as well as good biocompatibility. Especially nanomaterials brought significant advances in the design of novel paper-based biosensing systems or improvements of the existing devices such as EC [106–110], CL [60] and ECL sensors [4, 111–114], colorimetric [76, 115, 116] and fluorescence assays [117], as well as supercapacitor. These micro −/nano- materials can be immobilized on the PB-chips by means of physical adsorption, chemical covalent bonding, electrodeposition, etc. The micro- and nanomaterial-based PB-chips showed great potential for enhanced functions such as detection sensitivity, selectivity, stability, reproducibility, and accuracy. The kinds and merits of micro- and nanomaterials used in PB-chips and the corresponding applications have been summarized in Table 3.
Many materials including AuNPs [60, 106, 108, 123, 125], silver nanoparticles (AgNPs) [109, 115], graphene or graphene oxide (GO) [4, 107, 110], quantum dots [111, 114] and nanocomposites or hybrid nanosheets or alloy based on these materials [10, 76, 108, 110, 112, 113, 118–121, 124] have been applied in the paper-based biological and chemical
sensors. The micro- and nanomaterials used mainly play the roles as follows: (i) as ink material for electrode fabrication [106, 108, 109, 118, 121]; (ii) as signal reporters [111, 112, 115, 123]; (iii) as carriers to load signal markers [10, 107, 112]; (iv) as catalyst or amplification reagent to enhance the sensing signal [4, 60, 107, 110, 112, 113, 120, 124, 125].
Noble metal NPs and corresponding functions
Because of the good optical property, easy surface conjugation, high active surface area and controlled synthesis, noble metal particles including AuNPs [106, 108, 125], Au nanocages [113], Ag nanospheres [113], AgNPs [109, 115] and Pt particles [125] can be used as sensing reagents [115, 123] or for signal amplification [125] in colorimetric, CL, EC sensing on PB-chips [60, 106, 123]. For example, based on the AgNPs growth and clusters formation induced by ascorbic acid, a simple, highly sensitive and low cost colorimetric PBchip sensor was developed for ascorbic acid quantification. The sensitivity of the proposed sensor was comparable to the standard titration method when real samples were investigated [115]. Based on the mechanism that in the presence of AuNPs(+), H2O2 reacted with TMB to generate a bluish-green color, which became colorless upon reaction with UA. Paperbased colorimetric device was fabricated for highly sensitive uric acid (UA, 8.1 ppm) detection within <20min using 3,5,3′, 5′-tetramethyl benzidine (TMB), H2O2 and positively charged AuNPs(+). [123]. AuNPs can also co-work with other materials to modify the PB-chips. A 3D paper-based EC immunodevice for simultaneous sensitive detection of two tumor biomarkers can be fabricated with the assistance of nanoporous Pt particle and L-cysteine capped flowerlike AuNPs (Au–Cys). As a result, The immune-assay for simultaneous two tumor biomarkers detection was with wider linear ranges and low detection limit of ~1.0 pg mL−1 [125].
Carbon nanotubes and graphene as well as the corresponding functions
Carbon allotropes based materials have been using widely in many applications such as electronic devices and sensors [118]. Thereinto, carbon nanotubes and graphene are the rising promising nanomaterials as electrode materials in the PBchips due to their highly accessible specific surface area, unique nanoscale structures, good electrical conductivity and excellent stability under EC conditions [118, 121]. Paperbased electrodes of supercapacitor were conveniently fabricated with GO/single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT) composite ink via a dip casting method. By using different concentrations of SWCNT in the ink, the paper electrodes provide different capacitance values. The cycling stability for the GO– SWCNT paper electrode supercapacitors showed capacitance retention of 85 % over 60,000 cycles, indicating the good stability of the proposed electrode [118].In recent years, graphene has been attracting more and more attention since its debut in 2004. Functionalized graphene or graphene nanocomposite can be used to enhancing the amount and stability of immobilization for signal reporters such as Ru(bpy)3
2+. As a result, sensitive and reproducible EC immunoassay and ECL sensors have been established [4, 10, 107]. For instance, based on the composite film of poly(sodium 4-styrenesulfonate) functionalized graphene (PSSG) and Nafion, our group introduced highly efficient solid-state ECL sensor onto the screen printed electrodes of the PB-chips. Due to the cooperative characteristics of both PSS and graphene, PSSG ensured both effective Ru(bpy)3
2+ immobilization and fast electron transfer of Ru(bpy)3
2+ in the composite film [85]. In addition, accurate, rapid, simple, and inexpensive paper-based EC immunoassays was developed through the use of graphene to modify the EC immunodevice surface to accelerate the electron transfer and the use of silica NPs as a tracing tag to label the signal antibodies [107]. Besides, peroxidase-like nanomaterials such as graphene oxide@SiO2@CeO2 nanosheets [76] can be immobilized on PB-chips for H2O2 detection and also provided a biocompatible microenvironment for further enzyme immobilization.
Quantum dots (QDs) and corresponding functions
QDs such as CdTe, CdSe, and CdS have been usually used as signal labels such as for ECL labels in mechanism study, immunoassays and DNA detection [111, 117]. Shi et al. modifiedTa bl e 3

carbon tape electrodes with QDs and performed ECL detection in portable and inexpensive PB-chips. Due to the strong attachment of QDs on adhesive tapes, highly consistent ECL emission after 31 cycles of cyclic potential scan was still obtained for H2O2 reaction on the PB-chips [111]. Graphene quantum dots (GQDs) are relatively eco-friendly signal labeling agents compared with the CdTe or CdS QDs. Since the signals of pure GQDs are usually very weak, greenluminescent GQDs functionalized Au@Pt NPs were used as signal amplification labels in PB-chip based assays. The proposed ECL sensor on PB-chips showed excellent sensitivity for carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) detection (detection limit of 0.6 pg mL−1) [112].
Hybrid nanomaterials and corresponding functions
Many other micro- /nano-materials or composites have also been used for modification of the PB-chips, including silica NPs [107], porous magnetite [10], TiO2, manganese oxide (MnO2) nanowires [108] or hybrid materials based on the multiple requirements. For example, in developing an EC immunosensor for detection of prostate protein antigen on PB-chips, AuNPs and manganese oxide (MnO2) nanowires networks were sequentially grown on a freestanding three dimensional (3D) origami device. Due to the extremely large active surface areas of the nanocrystals, the PB-chips have demonstrated extraordinary electrocatalytic activities in electrochemical sensing of biomarker, high selectivity, reproducibility, and excellent stability [108]. Hybrid Pd/Fe3O4@Cmaterials can be used as mimic enzyme and integrated into the PB-chips for sensitive H2O2 detection [116].
Detection techniques and corresponding applications
In order to maintain the simplicity, affordability and portability of the lab-on-paper devices, suitable transduction techniques are required. The most commonly used techniques for lab-on-paper analysis are colorimetry [58, 126–128], EC [95, 129–131], CL [3, 103, 132–135], and ECL [136–140] (Fig. 1c). These allow for simple, fast and miniaturized processing detection techniques at affordable costs. Herein, taking the selected newest research works since November 2014 as examples, detection techniques were used as classification criteria to give the following description, showing the corresponding analytes, application fields for each detection technique (Table 4). Meanwhile, the specific advantages and limitations or problems resolved for the developed PB-chip based methodology have also been summarized (Table 4). This part is intended to give an idea on which method or strategy is appropriate for certain analytes and related practical areas.

sections.heading: Colorimetric detection and applications
sections.text:
Colorimetric detection, which can be achieved by visually comparing the color intensity of the reaction spots with the standards of known color intensity [12, 175], is the primary type of technique that used in the paper based analytical kits. It is the simplest and most frequently used one in PB-chips till now [116, 123, 141–149, 151–156, 176, 177], which can be used for analysis of proteins [116, 151, 155], drugs [142, 146, 147], inorganic ions [142, 144, 145, 153, 176], organic acids [123, 153], etc. (gathered in Table 4) involving various scientific fields such as environment monitoring, biomedical assay, food safety control, and so on. Furthermore, not only model molecules were analyzed, analytes in practical samples including human serum, foodstuff, environmental waters, etc. were also investigated (see Table 4).
Due to the flexible and easy-accessible detectors and readout such as camera and cell phone, colorimetric detection can be realized in laboratories with limited resources [144, 176]. For example, a paper-based chip was fabricated by patterning a filter paper with a permanent marker pen. Nitrite ion concentrations of both a pre-designed sample and a sample of pond water can be determined via the colorimetric assay performed on the PB-chips. The color change can be easily observed by bare eyes, after being recorded by a camera-phone, the data process for calculating the quantity can be achieved using computer software [151]. Additionally, Koesdjojo et al. developed a simple and direct method to fabricate paper-based microfluidic devices that can be used for a wide range of quantitative colorimetric analysis such as Fe2+ and Cu2+, using a widely accessible iPhone camera and a Red-GreenBlue (RGB) color reader application to measure color intensity [141]. It can be seen that the fabrication and detection process of the PB-chips for colorimetric analysis was simple, fast and of satisfactory sensitivity [123].
The smart design of lab-on-paper fabrication methods allows for both single component analysis and simultaneous detection of several analytes targets by colorimetry [142, 152]. For example, a versatile point-of-care paper-based assay platform was developed for simultaneous detection of multiple targets using a target-responsive hydrogel to mediate fluidic flow and signal readout, of which the lateral simulation diagram of one channel is shown in Fig. 5a. As can be seen in Fig. 5b, an aptamer-cross-linked hydrogel was used as the target responsive flow regulator in the PB-chips. In the absence of a target, the hydrogel is formed in the flow channel, stopping the flow in the PB-chips and preventing the colored indicator from travelling to the final observation spot, thus yielding Bsignal off^ readout. While in the presence of the target, no hydrogel is formed because of the preferential interaction of target and the aptamer. This allows free fluidic flow in the PB-chips, carrying the indicator to the observation spot and producing Bsignal on^ readout. Based on this design,

The proposed method confirmed the colorimetric detection combined with PB-chips have the great potential to provide simple, low cost, rapid, user-friendly, point-of-care testing in many applications [142].

sections.heading: Chemiluminescence detection and applications
sections.text:
CL detection, measuring light intensity generated from a chemical reaction, has gained much attention as a powerful detection technique in the PB-chips because of its inexpensive reagents, higher sensitivity and less instrumentation [27, 157–159, 178]. Analysis such as glucose in tear [157], medicine of ofloxacin in eyedrop sample [159], dichlorvos in vegetables [42, 158] as well as long DNA amplicons [178] have been carried out on the CL detection combined with PBchips recently. Generally, paper-based CL assays offer more accurate and sensitive results than conventional colorimetric assays [157]. For example, based on the enhancement of CL
intensity of luminal-H2O2-ofloxacin system by AgNPs, a sensitive wax-printed paper-based analytical device combined with luminol CL system was developed for ofloxacin detection. A low detection limit of 3.0 × 10−10 g.mL−1 was achieved [159]. The CL can also be used to excite photoelectrochemistry for competitive immunoassay of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) using CdS/TiO2 hybrid modified porous Au-paper electrode, a paper supercapacitor, a digital multi-meter as the working electrode, current-amplifier, terminal current detector, respectively. Under optimized conditions, this CL-based PB-chips can detect CEA in picomolar concentrations [165].

sections.heading: Electrochemical detection and applications
sections.text:
EC is a process that directly converts a biological or chemical event to an electronic signal [180]. Although it is a little more expensive than visual-based colorimetric detection, it is still an attractive alternative detection technique for PB-chips because of its small size, portability, low cost, high sensitivity,
high selectivity, and minimal instrumentation [12, 181]. Moreover, screen-printed carbon electrode offers excellent joint between the PB-chips and the detection methods due to its attractive advantages including low cost, disposability, flexibility in design, ease of chemical modification and fabrication with minimal outside technology [12]. As reported by Dungchai et al. [12], screen-printing technology can be used to fabricate electrodes on the paperbased microfluidic devices, which were demonstrated with excellent EC performance based on the multiple analysis of glucose, lactate, and uric acid in biological samples (see Fig. 6a). Paper pattern with eight working electrodes sharing one pair of counter and reference electrodes can also be screen-printed on a predesigned area of paper (Fig. 6b left). The as-prepared PB-chips were then modified with graphene oxide/Chitosan composite film to immobilize antibodies. Accordingly, paper-based EC immunodevice was developed for sensitive detection of cancer biomarkers (Fig. 6b right) [107].
Besides the two-dimensional PB-chips, 3D ones have also been proposed recently [182]. Figure 6c shows a typical 3D view of a paper based analytical devices having hollow channels (HC-PADs) before further assembly and application. Furthermore, a BY″ shaped design was applied to discuss the nature of the flow regime within the channels of the HCPADs. As shown in Fig. 6d left, oneWE is placed within each of the two separated streams thus the composition of each can be independently assayed. From the cyclic voltammograms (CVs) (see Fig. 6d right) obtained in the two separate branches of the hollow channels after the flow stopped, it can be seen that only 1,1′-ferrocenedimethanol (FcDM) is detected in the blue channel while mainly ferrocenemethanol [Fe(phen)3SO4] is observed in the red one. These results revealed the possibility of using these simple HC-PADs to quantitatively interpret the EC diagnostic results in the future [179].
By choosing detection potential and/or electrode material or different EC modes such as amperometric detection [131, 162, 183–185], potentiometric detection [169, 186, 187], etc.,
the PB-chips can be used for analysis of proteins in serum samples [165, 166, 171], glucose and H2O2 in beverages [162, 172], ions [167–169] in waters and foods as well as assessment in breathing process of red blood cells [163], multi-glycan expressions on cancer cells [170] and label-free detection of the protein binding activity [164]. Picomole level detection limit for analytes such as CEA in serum samples can be achieved using these inexpensive and simple EC methods (Details are shown in Table 4).

sections.heading: Electrochemiluminescence detection and applications
sections.text:
ECL, which emits measurable luminescent signals initiated by an EC reaction, is also an attractive alternative for lab-on-paper analysis. Most of the recent work involves in the development of new approaches to consolidate power and measurement for the integration of ECL with paper-based devices. Yu’s group carried out extensive works on paper-based ECL origami devices for sensitive detection of proteins [113, 114], cancer cells [124, 174], etc. with high selectivity. A detection limit as low as 0.15 f. of human IgG has been reached [114]. Besides, a disposable paper-based bipolar electrode (BPE) array was developed. This proposed BPE array device was composed of 15 units, each including six sensing cells and two reporting cells. The developed device showed excellent performances for multiplexed ECL detection of pathogenic DNAs such as syphilis (Treponema pallidum) gene, the immune deficiency virus gene and hepatitis B virus gene [173]. Our group proposed a series of measures to fabricate highly efficient solid-state ECL sensor onto the screen printed electrodes of the PB-chips based on functionalized graphenematerials via ion-exchanging, electrostatic attraction or direct pre-printing mixing methods [4, 10, 85] (Fig. 6e). The assay has excellent reproducibility (relative standard deviations of 0.63 % in 45 cycles) and longterm stability (~80 % of the initial ECL intensity is retained over 3 months at room temperature) [85]. Discrimination of 0.5 nM single-nucleotide mismatch in human urine matrix or sensitive detection of tetracycline hydrochloride was realized on a paper-based solid-state ECL sensor [10]. These works confirmed the good compatibility between solid-state ECL sensor and the PB-chips because of their same minimizingcost purpose. Attention should be paid to is that due to the opaqueness of the screen printed electrodes, the side with the working and counter electrodes were placed over against the PMT to collect the utmost ECL signal [4, 10, 85].
The electronic instrument or reader is significant to the cost of the analysis. Delaney et al. interrogated the paper-based ECL sensor using only a mobile phone, in which the audio output of the device was used to achieve EC control, while the camera was applied to detect the resulting light emitted during the ECL reaction. The combination of cell phone technology with lowcost paper microfluidic sensors dramatically reduces the cost of sensing and has great application potentials [133, 188].
Other detection methods used for PB-chips
Moreover, mass spectrometry detection, magneto-resistive sensors, nuclear magnetic resonance, fluorescence [22, 189, 190], Raman spectroscopy [47, 146, 191–195] have also begun to be applied in PB-chips [196–201]. Accordingly, the quantitative analysis of paper-based analytical kits has been addressed inmany fields such as diagnostic tests, environmental monitoring and food safety, etc. [27, 34]. The PB-chips were also used for blood typing and allowed for the simultaneous determination of ABO and Rh blood groups [202], for high-performance large-scale evaporation [203] and for temperature sensing and imaging [204], as well as pH sensing [177] etc. For example, a paper test card has been designed to perform an iodometric titration for quantifying 0.8–15 ppm of iodine atoms from iodate in aqueous solutions. The paperbased device is with wide application, e.g. to quantify iodine levels in fortified salt [205].

sections.heading: Conclusions and outlook
sections.text:
As the shining star in analytical chemistry and a hotspot among researchers all over the world, PB-chips have drawn considerable interests in many fields. They have extended from simple 1D lateral-flow systems to 3D microfluidic devices with complex microfluidic paths, fast separation and detection speed, enhanced accuracy and detection limit. Furthermore, most of the research efforts on PB-chips are also focused on minimizing fabrication steps and integrated into a miniaturized analytical system. Therefore, the miniaturized PB-chips significantly save the detection time and reduce the consumption of samples and reagents. Especially the booming 3D printing techniques are anticipated to print 3D origami-like device much more simply, conveniently and time-sparingly [101], while facilitate the PB-chips to combine multiple functions such as sample incubation, separation and detection.
However, the stability and reproducibility of the PB-chips should be paid to special attention, since paper and the printed materials on it (e.g. electrode) were so fragile that they are susceptible to alterations of bending, folding, tearing and long-time soaking in aqueous buffer or sample solution. These shortcomings can be reduced by choosing appropriate paper substrate such as NC and fabrication methods such as plotting one, or by rapid analysis time which shortens the exposure time of the PB-chips to adverse condition. In addition, the sensitivity of the PB-chip assays is limited for the most popular used detection method, colorimetry. Accordingly, the PB-chips based on EC and ECL detection techniques are supposed to attract more and more attention due to their high versatility, easy to use, real-time analysis with enhanced stability and especially sensitivity compared with other detection techniques. Meanwhile, as the EC and ECL
detections usually encounter interfering effects due to their intrinsic sensitive properties, the mass production for PBchips may provide easy availability for repeated tests to assure the good assay reproducibility.
Many new advanced micro−/nano- materials are emerging, such as nanosheets, nanotubes and QDs originating from the transition metal dichalcogenides [206], boron nitride [207], carbon nitride (C3N4) [208, 209], etc. These materials are more chemically versatile than carbon-based materials and cost-effective than noble metal particles. They are expected to provide paper-based analytical kits with more functions for further efficient applications. For example, C3N4 nanosheets are more attractive signal carrier matrix for metal nanoparticles immobilization and for subsequent biosensor fabrication [209]. In addition, the QDs generated from these kinds of materials will bring new chances for developing environment-friendly fluorescent and ECL signal labels or catalyst or immobilization matrix or signal amplification agents for assays on the PB-chips [210].
In practical assays, the inexpensive PB-chips can not only reduce the cost but also eliminate the risk of cross contamination by enabling one-time use of the devices. Despite the wide applications of the PB-chips in immunoassays, detections of proteins, inorganic and organic ions or molecules, other kinds of assays such as genetic assays (e.g. DNA sequencing, pathogen detection, and short tandem repeat analysis) [154, 211] and lateral flow assays [84, 199] are rarely transferred to the PB-chips. These should be due to the limited sensitivity of the PB-chips or some of these methods are time consuming and require more reagents for fabricating appropriate PB-chips. One challenge that must be addressed is how to make the on-chip DNA extraction suitable for integration with downstream steps in microchannels of the PB-chips. In addition, when dealing with raw samples, such as dry blood stains, most PB-chip systems still require lengthy manual operations to prepare the samples until now. With the future advances in suitable structure design, fabrication possess, modification based on the new advanced micro- /nano- materials and choosing sensitive appropriate detection techniques, PBchips will surely playmuchmore important roles in diagnostic tests, environmental monitoring, food safety and other fields.

metadata.abstractText: Paper-based chips (PB-chips; also referred to as lab-on-paper chips) are using patterned paper as a substrate in a lab-on-a-chip platform. They represent an outstanding technique for fabrication of analytical devices for multiplex analyte assays. Typical features include low-cost, portability, disposability and small sample consumption. This review (with 211 refs.) gives a comprehensive and critical insight into current trends in terms of materials and techniques for use in fabrication, modification and detection. Following an introduction into the principles of PB-chips, we discuss features of using paper in lab-on-a-chip devices and the proper choice of paper. We then discuss the versatile methods known for fabrication of PB-chips (ranging from photolithography, plasma treatment, inkjet etching, plotting, to printing including flexographic printing). The modification of PB-chips with microand nano-materials possessing superior optical or electronic properties is then reviewed, and the final section covers detection techniques (such as colorimetry, electrochemistry, electrochemiluminescence and chemiluminescence) along with specific (bio)analytical examples. A conclusion and outlook section discusses the challenges and future prospectives in this field.
